abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated unsatisfactory.
            By today's standards of practice in the World Bank, the
            project objectives were not formulated clearly enough and
            were too ambitious. In particular, the objectives should
            have reflected a more realistic vision of what one project
            could accomplish, given the inherently risky nature of
            governance reforms, the severly limited implementation
            capacity of both the central and local governments, and the
            long time horizon needed for local governments to achieve
            the capacity to provide and maintain essential service.
            Project sustainability--that is, sustainable financing for
            Assembly capital investments, the ability of the Assemblies
            to sustain these investments through proper operations and
            maintenance procedures, and the sustainability of the
            "enabling framework" of laws, policies, and
            institutions for local government development and eventual
            service provision by the Assemblies. Both Bank and Borrower
            performances are rated unsatisfactory overall. Some of the
            lessons learned centered on the need to establish a strong
            project unit with strong financial and technical skills.
            Risk assessment and mitigation in project design need to be
            much more rigorous, including the scaling down of projects
            if needed. Bank supervision missions need to be critically
            honest. Building on the points mentioned, projects need to
            be designed in a performance driven way; this requires the
            early design, adoption, and implementation of a rigorous
            monitoring system.
